ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Relationship of person completing questionnaire (parent/guardian informant) - collapsing categories
Notes: 1 = Adolescent; 2 = Mother figure; 3 = Father figure; 4= Other

ElementDescription: Question 1: The best way to describe this program is as:
Notes: 1 = Education to make families and teenagers aware of emotional problems 2 = A research study 3 = A program for delivering free care

ElementDescription: Question 2: To participate in this program, teenagers must:
Notes: 1 = Have learning problems 2 = Be suffering from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder 3 = Be suffering from depression

ElementDescription: Question 3: I understand that the main goal for doctors in this program is:
Notes: 1 = To find out which type of treatment works best for teenagers with depression 2 = To give free care to teenagers with depression 3 = To offer a new treatment that is available only in research studies

ElementDescription: Question 4: Possible treatments in this program include:
Notes: 1 = A medication called fluoxetine and a type of psychotherapy called cognitive- behavioral therapy 2 = A medication called imipramine and skill training for parents 3 = A medication called paroxetine and a type of psychotherapy called interpersonal therapy

ElementDescription: Question 5: Before starting the program:
Notes: 1 = I was given little or no information about the program 2 = The doctor(s) told me about the program and answered my questions 3 = The study doctor(s) didn't say much so I found the information elsewhere

ElementDescription: Question 6: Before starting the program:
Notes: 1 = I wasn't asked if I would agree to participate 2 = I verbally agreed to participate 3 = I signed a consent form agreeing to participate

ElementDescription: Question 7: During the first 12 weeks of this program:
Notes: 1 = All teens who take pills are given �active� medication 2 = Some teens are given a �real� medication and other teens are given an �inactive� medication 3 = All teens are given �inactive� medication for 1 month before they can receive �real� medication

ElementDescription: Question 8: When I agreed to participate in this program, the chance of being assigned to inactive medication for the first 12 weeks was:
Question 9: Before starting this program:
Notes: 1 = I was told that there were benefits but not risks to participating 2 = I was told that there were benefits and risks to participating 3 = I was not told of benefits or risks to participating

ElementDescription: Question 10: At the time I agreed to participate in this program:
Notes: 1 = I was told of other treatments that could be used for depression 2 = I was told that no other treatments for depression were available 3 = I was told that treatments offered in this program were available only in research studies

ElementDescription: Question 11: After I gave my permission to participate in this program:
Notes: 1 = I couldn't quit even if I wanted to 2 = I had the right to stop participating at any time, even if the study was not finished 3 = I could quit the program but only if the doctors said OK

ElementDescription: Question 12: The choice of study treatment was decided:
Notes: 1 = Randomly 2 = I got to choose which treatment I wanted 3 = The doctors chose the treatment based on what was best for each teen

ElementDescription: Question 13: The single most important reason for participating in this program is that we:
Notes: 1 = Wanted to contribute to advancing scientific knowledge 2 = Needed free care that we could not afford otherwise 3 = Liked the payments that study offered for filling out the study forms 4 = Were curious about what a program like this was about 5 = Wanted the best possible care 6 = Other

ElementDescription: Question 14: Before this program started, we (the teen and family):
Notes: 1 = Agreed from the beginning about participating 2 = Sort of agreed about participating 3 = Disagreed about participating

ElementDescription: Form used/assessment name
Notes: e.g., Self-Report, Parent Form, Short Form, Revised Version

ElementDescription: Patient consented
days since randomization
Numeric Visit Number
Notes: -1.5 = Pre-Screening; -1 = Screening; 0 = Baseline; ## = Visit ## (from 1 to 10); Whole numbers = standard monthly visits; #.001 - #.009 = Unscheduled; #.1 = End of Phase 1; #.2 = End of Phase 2; #.3 = End of Phase 3; #.4 = End of Open Choice Phase; #.5 = End of Study; #.6 = Genetic Analysis; 1000=all visits

ElementDescription: Site
consent days since randomization
Time of day the assessment was taken. Hour:minutes
Visit name
All study publications will mention me by name.
I will be expected to give blood through a finger stick at each visit.
I will receive an experimental medication in this study.
I may contact the Yale Institutional Review Board if I have questions about my rights as a research participant.
Were any incorrect questions reviewed with the participant?
Was this participant previously screened and is now being consented for a second time?
Participation in this research study is my decision.
I will not lose access to any services at this hospital or any other negative consequences if I choose not to participate.
Any information I provide to the study staff can be shared with anyone who asks for it.
If I choose to participate, I will be randomly assigned (luck of the draw), to one of 3 treatment options.
I will be assigned to treatment based on my favorite color.
If I complete the study visits I will be paid a total of $225 in gift cards or combination tablet and gift cards.
This study will consist of 3 visits.
